title: Soldier wants military honors for service dog in WY
text:
POWELL, WY (KTWO/CNN) - Major Mike spent two tours in Iraq, sniffing for explosives, chasing enemy combatants and saving the lives of fellow soldiers, only to be shot and killed at his home in Wyoming.
For Army veteran Matthew Bessler, it was heartbreaking.
“I lost a great companion,” Bessler said of his service dog. “Me and him were healing together.”
Bessler got Mike when he was just a puppy. The two were inseparable, from their time overseas to back at home in Wyoming.
“He was my brother. Everywhere I went, he was right there. He was doing his job as a service animal,” Bessler said.
Both Bessler and Mike were retired from the service due to post traumatic stress disorder. Bessler adopted Mike after their last deployment, and his wartime partner became his service dog as they battled life after combat.
“He helped me through a lot of different situations and a lot of different emotional times.” Bessler said of Mike.
Bessler lost his best friend and brother when Mike was shot and killed by a bicyclist. Like any story, there are two sides. The man who shot Mike believed he was  being attacked.
“I was paralyzed. I was shocked. I’m still in shock, anger, sadness, pain,” Bessler said of the loss of Mike.
And now, he wants to honor his fellow soldier by giving him a proper veteran burial with military honors. However, military dogs aren’t entitled to receive military honors - a policy Bessler is hoping to change.
“He’s retired just like I’m retired,” he said. “I’ll receive military honors. I’m a veteran. He’s a veteran...dog.”
As he pushes for change, Bessler said he just needs time to grieve.
“there are a number of other veterans out there that are looking for dogs, and they need them,” he said.
After Mike was retired, he was promoted to Major. And even though he wasn’t on the front lines, his service never stopped.
Through the help of a Go Fund Me page , over $14,000 was raised in less than a week to give him a funeral worthy of a hero, to be held Nov. 11 at the Power cemetery.
